fields.title: UNICEF Mozambique Cyclone Idai Situation Report #4 (01 – 05 April 2019)
fields.body:
**Highlights**

- At least 142,327 people have been displaced from Cyclone Idai and the severe flooding. Most of the displaced are hosted in 139 transit centers set up in Sofala, Manica, Zambezia and Tete provinces. 

- Between 27 March and 6 April 2019, 2,772 cholera cases were recorded in Beira, Dondo, Buzi and Nhamatanda and five fatalities in Beira and Dondo.

- On 2 April, UNICEF airlifted oral cholera vaccines (OCV) to support the vaccination campaign. So far, 429,177 people in Sofala province have been reached representing about 51 per cent of the target population.

- UNICEF is supporting the operational running costs (fuel, generators, and large quantities of water treatment chemicals) for urban water systems in Beira, Dondo and Nhamatanda, with 416,000 people accessing safe water.

- UNICEF is actively engaging government and NGO partners in promoting an environment free of Sexual Exploitation and Abuse (SEA) and Sexual Harassment (SH). Jointly with UNFPA, UNHCR, PLAN, Save the Children International, UNICEF developed an orientation curriculum on child protection, gender based violence (GBV), PSEA and trained 127 volunteers in Beira, with trainings currently ongoing in Chimoio

- UNICEF and COSACA consortium are setting up temporary learning spaces benefitting 2,640 children in accommodation centres in the districts of Beira and Dondo.

**SITUATION IN NUMBERS**

**1.85 million** People in need by the cyclone/floods defined by HRP 2019

**1 million** Children in need by the cyclone/floods

**500,000** Children targeted through humanitarian interventions by UNICEF

**965,000** People targeted through humanitarian interventions by UNICEF

**2,772** Cholera cases reported in Sofala Province

**Situation Overview and Humanitarian Needs**

The Ministry of Health launched a cholera vaccination campaign on 03 April in the areas affected by the cyclone. The campaign is covering Beira city and other districts including Dondo, Nhamatanda and Buzi. The vaccination campaign is being carried out in accommodation centres, health units and mobile units with 884,000 people expected to be vaccinated.  

As of 6 April, there were 2,772 cholera cases recorded in Beira, Dondo, Buzi and Nhamatanda and death toll of 05 people.Most of the cases have been reported in Beira (2,188 cases), followed by Nhamatanda (271 cases), and Dondo (289). On 04 April, the health authorities confirmed new cases of cholera in Buzi distric,t with 24 cases by 06 April. The cholera taskforce is holding daily meetings in Beira to inform operational response and community sensitization is on-going on radio and through printed communication materials to convey messages related to communicable disease control and when to seek health-care. There are 14 cholera treatment centres (CTC) in Sofala – eight in Beira city, three in Nhamatanda and the remaining in Dondo and Buzi.  

The Ministry of Health through the National Institute of Health and partners continue collecting samples of water sources in cholera affected areas and together with other line ministries carry out measures on sanitation, education, community mobilisation, and water trucking and distribution of CERTEZA.  

According to the National Institute for Disaster Management (INGC), at least 1,514,445 people were affected by the cyclone and floods in the central region of the country and the death toll has risen to 602. Reportedly, at least 223,898 houses were partially or totally destroyed.  

As of 07 April, 142,327 people have been displaced due to the cyclone and flooding. The displaced people are largely hosted in 139 transit centres in Sofala, Manica, Zambezia and Tete provinces. The largest number of transit centres are in Sofala where at least 121,322 people are hosted in 111 centres. From 1 – 5 April the Government closed at least 17 transit centres, most of them in Zambezia and Sofala provinces relocating about 4,142 people to new locations. In some cases families have been assigned land plots. According to INGC at least 263,181 students are affected by the floods and cyclones due to the damage of 3,359 classrooms in Sofala, Manica,  
Zambezia and Tete provinces. At least 54 health facilities are affected in Sofala, Manica and Zambézia.  

Access by road remains a challenge in several areas. Preliminary reports from a joint Government-inter-agency mission from Vilankulos to Sofala Province indicate that Chibabava is accessible by road and surrounding remote areas remain accessible by air only. There are five collective centres in Chibabava, only one of which (Xinhika) is reachable by road. The rest (Goonda Madjaca (403 households), Gerome (375 households), Xinhica Mudava (142 households), Xiquaxa (93 households) and Escola Secundaria File Jacnto Nyusse (09 households) are not reachable by road but have received some assistance by air from Beira. The Buzi district, the most flood affected area, is now accessible by road. However, Buzi north remains difficult to access but accessibility is expected to improve as repairs continues.
